Award.AwardTitle: Order and Disorder in Strongly Segregated Block Copolymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Block copolymers constitute one of the fastest growing segments of the polymer industry, which accounts for more than $300B annually of commerce in North America. These materials are prepared by coupling together two or more chemically distinct linear polymer chains, resulting in macromolecules endowed with multiple functionality and multifaceted physical properties that derive from segregation of the polymer blocks on a nanometer scale. Modern technical applications of block copolymers, for example in the microelectronics industry, require constantly diminishing and more complex nanoscale structures, below the limits set by current theoretical knowledge and practical understanding. This project aims to establish the fundamental principles that govern block copolymer phase behavior and mechanical properties in this new structural limit. Model materials, containing various combinations of two, three or more polymer blocks will be synthesized by controlled polymerization and characterized using small-angle x-ray and neutron scattering, electron microscopy, dynamic mechanical spectroscopy, and a host of other sophisticated techniques. These materials will be prepared near the order-disorder transition (ODT) by tightly controlling molecular weight and composition. The ODT represents a key processing parameter for designing multiblock copolymers for subsequent applications. The findings of this work are intended to spur new theoretical developments along with exciting practical applications.


NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Polymeric materials, including plastics and elastomers, medical devices and pharmaceutical aids, and key elements of the microelectronics industry constitute one of the most important commercial drivers in the nation's economy. This research program will guide the development of new and more versatile polymeric materials while educating the next generation of scientists and engineers working in this critical area of technology. New and more demanding applications of synthetic polymers mandates the development of microscopic structural features at nanometer length scales, thousands of times smaller than the diameter of a human hair. The scientific and engineering goals will be achieved through state of the art synthetic chemistry coupled with sophisticated structural analysis and physical property evaluation. This technical program will provide industry with competitive tools for the design and implementation of new and innovative products. Interest in science and engineering will be fostered in students in grades 3-12 through an interactive program called Energy and U. This activity brings thousands of students and numerous families to the University annually for an experience that stimulates awe and excitement while teaching important lessons about energy and society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Synthetic polymers are giant molecules that are beneficial to innumerable aspects of life, ranging from the lightweight materials that makes modern windmills feasible and automobiles and aircraft more fuel efficient, to key ingredients in the manufacturing of computer chips, and as enabling components in medical devices such as artificial heart valves and hip replacements. Expanding the portfolio of such applications, while simultaneously ameliorating adverse effects associated with disposal of these remarkable materials, drives a quest to improve properties by combining polymer molecules into hybrid compounds known as block copolymers. This research project explored the fundamental principles associated with the development of nanoscale structure in A-B diblock copolymers, the simplest variant of this expansive class of macromolecular compounds. A diblock copolymer is formed by joining two chemically different linear polymer chains end-to-end. Basic thermodynamic principles drive the two blocks to segregate on the nanoscale producing a rich array of ordered and disordered morphologies, which impart desirable physical properties. Two thrusts were aimed at uncovering the fundamental relationships that govern the formation of layered bicontinuous microemulsion phases, and spherical micelle particles that assemble into a plethora of 3-dimensional ordered states.

 Diblock copolymers were synthesized using controlled anionic polymerization leading to the formation of molecules with precisely specified compositions and molecular weights. Roughly equal volume fractions of the A and B blocks produced a lamellar morphology. The length scale of this periodic layered structure was dilated by the addition of A and B homopolymers, leading to the formation of a bicontinuous microemulsion. This fascinating state of regular yet disordered structure was explored using small-angle X-ray and neutron scattering techniques, transmission electron microscopy, and the viscoelastic properties were probed by dynamic mechanical spectroscopy. This work revealed previously unrecognized features in the 4-dimensional phase prism formed by the 3 composition variables and temperature, establishing certain universal principles applicable to all diblock copolymer and homopolymers mixtures along with analogies to the phase behavior of oil-water-surfactant systems.

Compositionally asymmetric diblock copolymers, containing a short A block and a long B block, self-assemble into spherical particles that order at low temperature into 3-dimensional crystalline structures. Prior to this research program the body centered cubic (BCC) phase was the only such structure anticipated by theory and realized experimentally. Extensive experimentation with low molecular weight A-B diblocks that form strongly segregated micelles in both the ordered and disordered states led to the discovery of 3 new periodic crystalline phases and an aperiodic phase known as a quasicrystal in these diblock materials. These structures belong to a category of low symmetry crystals known as Frank-Kasper phases, which are also prevalent in metals and alloys. These discoveries pointed to a new symmetry parameter, referred to as conformational asymmetry, which plays a pivotal role in the packing of dense arrays of soft matter particles. Conformational asymmetry accounts for differences in the volume of space pervaded by the flexible A and B chains configured in the core and corona of the micelles, respectively. Competition between the constraints imposed by the molecular composition (actual volume occupied by each block), conformational asymmetry, and the driving force for the micelles to be spherical in shape, dictates the particle packing symmetry.

Also discovered was that the formation of specific crystalline phases is strongly influenced by the thermal processing history. When slowly cooled from the disordered state development of the BCC phase is followed by transformation to the Frank-Kasper sigma phase. Rapid cooling produced a metastable dodecagonal quasicrystal that transformed to sigma phase over time, suggesting that aperiodic order is metastable. Dropping the disordered melt into liquid nitrogen followed by reheating led to the formation of the Frank-Kasper C14 and C15 phases. This path dependent behavior has strong analogies with the field of metallurgy, offering enticing opportunities to establish unified approaches to understanding symmetry breaking across the conceptual divides that separate our understanding of soft and hard materials.

During the course of this program a thrilling educational show entitled ‘Energy and U’ was presented 30 times annually to over 10,000 3rd to 6th graduate students, more than half from underrepresented groups, from around the Twin Cities. Created by the principal investigator and faculty colleagues, and delivered in collaboration with the Performing Arts Center at the University Minnesota, this awe inspiring show opens the minds of young people to the excitement and opportunities associated with science and engineering while teaching the first law of thermodynamics through spectacular demonstrations including explosions, fireballs, and much more. Data collected between 2015 and 2018 demonstrate a dramatic comprehension among participants of the concept that energy cannot be created or destroyed.
